awd_titl_txt: CPS: Frontier: Collaborative Research: Data-Driven Cyberphysical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Data-driven cyber-physical systems are ubiquitous in many sectors including manufacturing, automotive, transportation, utilities and health care. This project develops the theory, methods and tools necessary to answer the central question "how can we, in a data-rich world, design and operate cyber-physical systems differently?" The resulting data-driven techniques will transform the design and operation process into one in which data and models - and human designers and operators - continuously and fluently interact. This integrated view promises capabilities beyond its parts. Explicitly integrating data will lead to more efficient decision-making and help reduce the gap from model-based design to system deployment. Furthermore, it will blend design- and run-time tasks, and help develop cyber-physical systems not only for their initial deployment but also for their lifetime.

While proposed theory, methods and tools will cut across the spectrum of cyber-physical systems, the project focuses on their implications in the emerging application of additive manufacturing. Even though a substantial amount of engineering time is spent, additive manufacturing processes often fail to produce acceptable geometric, material or electro-mechanical properties. Currently, there is no mechanism for predicting and correcting these systematic, repetitive errors nor to adapt the design process to encompass the peculiarities of this manufacturing style. A data-driven cyber-physical systems perspective has the potential to overcome these challenges in additive manufacturing. The project's education plan focuses on the already much needed transformation of the undergraduate and graduate curricula to train engineers and computer scientists who will create the next-generation of cyber-physical with a data-driven mindset. The team will reach out to K-12 students and educators through a range of activities, and to undergraduate students from underrepresented groups through year-long research projects. All educational material generated by the project will be shared publicly.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
They key deliverables for this project are the design and validation of data-driven learning and control algorithms for additive manufacturing (AM) processes. Towards this goal, we report the following outcomes

(1) For data-driven control of Inkjet 3D printing, we have successfully developed and validated a hybrid data- and physics- based model with online update capability, which can be used for online model updates in a layer-to-layer model predictive control (MPC) framework. Additionally, we designed and experimentally validated a physics-guided convolutional-RNN model that captures droplet deposition, spreading, and shrinkage. We have demonstrated that this model requires far-less data for training than a black-box model and outperforms purely physics-based models in terms of predicting height evolution.  We obtained analytical guarantees for stability for the open-loop system. The connections between convergence of the learning algorithm and the open-loop stability were also discovered. Based on this convolutional-RNN model, we designed and experimentally validated a feedforward predictive control in which the network parameters are learned offline from previous data and the control input pattern for all layers to be printed is synthesized. Finally, we designed an algorithm for efficiently implementing feedback predictive control in which the network parameters and input patterns (for the receding horizon) are learned online with no added lead time for computation. The feedforward control scheme was shown experimentally to improve the RMS reference tracking error by more than 30 % over the state of the art control strategies. We also experimentally demonstrated on an inkjet 3D printing platform that process uncertainties are indeed compensated by the online learning and feedback control. 

(2) For metal AM processes such as selective laser melting (SLM), we created a build-area temperature monitoring setup using a thermal (long-wavelength infrared) camera and demonstrated real-time feedback control of laser power for regulating melt pool characteristics using measurements from this camera. We also used a data-driven iterative learning control alorithm for designing optimized power profiles for a specific layer geometry.  We also determined input-output process models from data collected from coaxial images of the melt pool. We ascertained that first order models can capture gross behavior of the melt pool response to changes in laser power. Further, we showed that these models are indeed dependent on layer number, scan speed, and local geometry, leading us to conclude that learning algorithms that take into account these factors are necessary for control. Based on these models, we created a framework for layer to layer learning to control process parameters based on coaxial and off axis images collected during the process. We have also designed and validated a line-to-line data-driven control strategy that exploits the fact that laser scanning of narrow features in SLM parts results in predictable changes in melt pool geometry as observed in coaxial melt pool images. To compensate for this systematic process deviation we designed and experimentally validated an empirical model of this geometry-related behavior. We then designed a model-based feedforward controller is to correct for this behavior. The proposed controller reduces geometry-related deviations by a factor of two, as demonstrated experimentally on an SLM testbed.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/15/2022
Modified by: Sandipan Mishra
por.por_txt_cntn:
They key deliverables for this project are the design and validation of data-driven learning and control algorithms for additive manufacturing (AM) processes. Towards this goal, we report the following outcomes

(1) For data-driven control of Inkjet 3D printing, we have successfully developed and validated a hybrid data- and physics- based model with online update capability, which can be used for online model updates in a layer-to-layer model predictive control (MPC) framework. Additionally, we designed and experimentally validated a physics-guided convolutional-RNN model that captures droplet deposition, spreading, and shrinkage. We have demonstrated that this model requires far-less data for training than a black-box model and outperforms purely physics-based models in terms of predicting height evolution.  We obtained analytical guarantees for stability for the open-loop system. The connections between convergence of the learning algorithm and the open-loop stability were also discovered. Based on this convolutional-RNN model, we designed and experimentally validated a feedforward predictive control in which the network parameters are learned offline from previous data and the control input pattern for all layers to be printed is synthesized. Finally, we designed an algorithm for efficiently implementing feedback predictive control in which the network parameters and input patterns (for the receding horizon) are learned online with no added lead time for computation. The feedforward control scheme was shown experimentally to improve the RMS reference tracking error by more than 30 % over the state of the art control strategies. We also experimentally demonstrated on an inkjet 3D printing platform that process uncertainties are indeed compensated by the online learning and feedback control. 

(2) For metal AM processes such as selective laser melting (SLM), we created a build-area temperature monitoring setup using a thermal (long-wavelength infrared) camera and demonstrated real-time feedback control of laser power for regulating melt pool characteristics using measurements from this camera. We also used a data-driven iterative learning control alorithm for designing optimized power profiles for a specific layer geometry.  We also determined input-output process models from data collected from coaxial images of the melt pool. We ascertained that first order models can capture gross behavior of the melt pool response to changes in laser power. We then designed a model-based feedforward controller is to correct for this behavior. The proposed controller reduces geometry-related deviations by a factor of two, as demonstrated experimentally on an SLM testbed.
